grammar.practical: From k-s-b (to earn). 'Kasabat' = 'it (feminine) earned'. We saw this in verse 281! Every soul gets the reward of what IT earned - its good deeds. The 't' ending shows third person feminine singular, agreeing with 'nafs'.

words.translation: And upon it / And against it

grammar.type: Harf + Harf + Ism - Conjunction + Preposition + Pronoun
grammar.reason: Parallel structure but opposite: UPON it (as a burden). The 'hā' refers to the soul.
grammar.practical: 'Wa' (and) + ''alā' (upon) + 'hā' (it). ''Alayhā' = 'upon it' or 'against it'. While good deeds are FOR the soul (benefit), now comes what's UPON it (burden)...

grammar.reason: What the soul earned of EVIL. Form VIII 'iktasaba' sometimes implies earning evil, intensifying the effort involved.
grammar.practical: 'Mā' (what) + 'iktasabat' (it earned). Form VIII of k-s-b. 'Iktasabat' is often used specifically for earning evil or sin, while 'kasabat' is general or good. Beautiful balance: you get the benefit of your good ('kasabat') and bear the burden of your evil ('iktasabat'). Perfect divine justice!

grammar.reason: Beginning the beautiful du'ā (supplication). Calling upon Allah: O OUR LORD!
grammar.practical: 'Rabbanā' = 'Our Lord' (vocative - calling upon Allah). This begins one of the most beautiful and comprehensive supplications in the Quran. Notice how 'rabbanā' is repeated throughout - constant turning to Allah!

words.translation: Do not take us to account / Do not blame us

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Negation + Command Verb (negative) + Pronoun
grammar.components: lā (not) + tu'ākhidh (You take to account) + nā (us)
grammar.reason: First request: DON'T hold us accountable. Form III 'ā-kha-dha' means to hold accountable, to blame.
grammar.practical: 'Lā' (not) + 'tu'ākhidhnā' (You take us to account). From a-kh-dh (to take). Form III 'ākhādha' means to hold to account, to blame. The long ā is characteristic of Form III. 'Nā' = us. 'Lā tu'ākhidhnā' = 'Do not hold us accountable' - a plea for Allah's mercy!

words.translation: If we forget / If we have forgotten

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conditional + Past Tense Verb
grammar.reason: Condition: IF we forgot. The 'nā' shows 'we' are the subject. Asking Allah not to punish for unintentional forgetfulness.
grammar.practical: 'In' (if) + 'nasīnā' (we forgot). From n-s-y (to forget). 'Nasīnā' = 'we forgot' - first person plural (the 'nā' ending). Don't hold us accountable IF we forgot - acknowledging human weakness and asking for divine mercy for unintentional mistakes!

words.translation: Or we erred / Or we made a mistake

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Disjunctive + Past Tense Verb
grammar.root: خ-ط-أ (kh-ṭ-') - to err, to make a mistake
grammar.reason: Alternative condition: OR we made a mistake. Covers both forgetfulness and unintentional error.
grammar.practical: 'Aw' (or) + 'akhṭa'nā' (we erred). From kh-ṭ-' (to err/make mistake). Form IV 'akhṭa'a' means to make an error, to commit a mistake. 'Nā' = we. Together: 'if we forgot OR if we erred' - covering all unintentional mistakes. Beautiful that this du'ā asks forgiveness for human weakness!

words.translation: Our Lord, and do not lay / Our Lord, and do not impose

grammar.type: Complete phrase - Vocative + Conjunction + Negation + Command Verb
grammar.root: ح-م-ل (ḥ-m-l) - to carry, to bear, to lay
grammar.reason: Second request: and DON'T lay/impose. 'Taḥmil' = You impose.
grammar.practical: 'Rabbanā' (Our Lord - vocative again) + 'wa' (and) + 'lā' (not) + 'taḥmil' (You lay/carry). From ḥ-m-l (to carry/bear). 'Taḥmil' is jussive mood (negative command): 'Do not lay...' Second supplication beginning.

grammar.reason: Where not to lay the burden: UPON US.
grammar.practical: ''Alā' (upon) + 'nā' (us). ''Alaynā' = 'upon us'. Don't lay upon US...

grammar.reason: What not to impose: A BURDEN - a heavy, restrictive obligation. Object of 'taḥmil'.
grammar.practical: From a-ṣ-r (to bind/restrict). 'Iṣr' means a heavy burden, restrictive obligation, something that binds and restricts. Tanwīn 'an' shows accusative (object). Don't lay upon us a heavy burden...

words.translation: Like what You laid it / As You laid it

grammar.reason: Comparison: LIKE the burden You laid. 'Ḥamalta' = You (singular) laid, 'hu' = it.
grammar.practical: 'Ka' (like/as) + 'mā' (what) + 'ḥamaltahu' (You laid it). 'Ḥamalta' = 'You laid' (second person singular past tense - addressing Allah). 'Hu' = it (the burden). 'Kamā ḥamaltahu' = 'as You laid it' - referring to the heavy burdens on previous nations.

grammar.reason: Upon WHOM the previous burdens were laid: those who came before us (previous nations).
grammar.practical: ''Alā alladhīna' (upon those who) + 'min qablinā' (before us). 'Qabl' = before, 'nā' = us. The previous nations had heavy restrictions (like those on Bani Israel). This du'ā asks Allah to make Islam easy, not burdensome like previous laws!

words.translation: Our Lord, and do not burden us

grammar.type: Complete phrase - Vocative + Negation + Command Verb + Pronoun
grammar.components: rabbanā (Our Lord) + wa (and) + lā (not) + tuḥammil (You burden) + nā (us)
grammar.reason: Third request: DON'T burden us. Form II intensifies: to make someone carry, to burden heavily.
grammar.practical: 'Rabbanā' (Our Lord) + 'wa lā' (and not) + 'tuḥammilnā' (You burden us). Form II of ḥ-m-l makes it causative/intensive: to MAKE carry, to burden. The doubled 'm' is characteristic of Form II. Third supplication begins.

words.translation: What we have no ability to bear

grammar.root: ط-و-ق (ṭ-w-q) - to have ability, to be capable
grammar.reason: WHAT not to burden us with: that which we have NO ability for.
grammar.practical: 'Mā' (what) + 'lā ṭāqata' (no ability/capacity) + 'lanā' (for us) + 'bihi' (with it). 'Ṭāqah' from ṭ-w-q means ability, capacity, power. 'Lā ṭāqata lanā bihi' = 'we have no ability for it'. Don't burden us with what we CAN'T bear - beyond our capability!

words.translation: And pardon us / And overlook our faults

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conjunction + Command Verb + Preposition + Pronoun
grammar.root: ع-ف-و ('a-f-w) - to pardon, to overlook, to efface
grammar.reason: First of three positive requests: PARDON us. 'I'fu' is command form addressing Allah.
grammar.practical: 'Wa' (and) + 'i'fu' (pardon!) + ''annā' (from us/'an + nā). From '-f-w (to pardon/overlook). 'I'fu' is the command form: 'Pardon!' ''Annā' = 'from us' or 'us'. First positive request after the negative ones: Pardon us, overlook our faults!

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conjunction + Command Verb + Preposition + Pronoun
grammar.root: غ-ف-ر (gh-f-r) - to forgive, to cover sins
grammar.reason: Second positive request: FORGIVE us. Command form addressing Allah.
grammar.practical: 'Wa' (and) + 'ighfir' (forgive!) + 'lanā' (for us). From gh-f-r (forgiveness). 'Ighfir' is command form: 'Forgive!' 'Lanā' = 'for us'. Second request: forgive our sins, cover our faults!

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Conjunction + Command Verb + Pronoun
grammar.root: ر-ح-م (r-ḥ-m) - to have mercy, to be compassionate
grammar.reason: Third positive request: have MERCY on us. The 'nā' is attached directly to the verb.
grammar.practical: 'Wa' (and) + 'irḥamnā' (have mercy on us). From r-ḥ-m (mercy). 'Irḥam' is command + 'nā' (us) attached. Three beautiful requests building on each other: pardon (efface), forgive (cover), and have mercy (be compassionate)!

words.translation: You are our Protector / You are our Master

grammar.root: و-ل-ي (w-l-y) - to be close, to protect, to be master
grammar.reason: Declaration of Allah's relationship to us: YOU are our Protector! 'Mawlā' means protector, master, guardian.
grammar.practical: 'Anta' (You - emphatic) + 'mawlānā' (our protector). 'Mawlā' from w-l-y means protector, guardian, master, patron. 'Nā' = our. 'Anta mawlānā' = 'YOU are our Protector/Master!' Acknowledging complete dependence on Allah before making final request.

words.translation: So give us victory / So help us

grammar.type: Harf + Fi'l - Connector + Command Verb + Pronoun
grammar.root: ن-ص-ر (n-ṣ-r) - to help, to give victory, to support
grammar.reason: Final request: THEREFORE give us victory! The 'fa' shows it follows from being our Protector.
grammar.practical: 'Fa' (so/therefore) + 'unṣurnā' (help us/give us victory). From n-ṣ-r (victory/help). 'Unṣur' is command + 'nā' (us). 'Fanṣurnā' = 'So help us' or 'So give us victory'. The 'fa' shows logical connection: SINCE You are our Protector, THEREFORE help us!

grammar.root: ك-ف-ر (k-f-r) - to disbelieve, to be ungrateful
grammar.reason: Over WHOM to give victory: over the disbelieving people. Final words of the surah!
grammar.practical: ''Alā' (over) + 'al-qawmi' (the people) + 'al-kāfirīn' (the disbelievers). 'Qawm' = people/nation. 'Kāfirīn' from k-f-r (disbelief) - plural of 'kāfir' (disbeliever). Give us victory OVER the disbelieving people. Perfect ending to the surah: acknowledging Allah as Protector and seeking His help against those who oppose truth. Final words of the longest surah in the Quran!
